column1: '''The Riddle of Strider''' is a poem by [[Bilbo Baggins]] in honour of [[Aragorn]]
column2: written when Aragorn first revealed his true identity to Bilbo.

column1: :''All that is gold does not glitter
column2:
''
''Not all those who wander are lost;''
''The old that is strong does not wither
column3:
''
''Deep roots are not reached by the frost.''

''From the ashes a fire shall be woken
column4:
''
''A light from the shadows shall spring;''
''Renewed shall be [[Andúril|blade that was broken]]
column5:
''
''The crownless again shall be [[Kings of Gondor|king]].

column1: The poem is first given in [[Gandalf's letter|the letter]] left for [[Frodo Baggins|Frodo]] by [[Gandalf]] in [[Bree]]. In that letter
column2: it appears as part of a postscript reminding Frodo to make sure that the "[[Strider (Aragorn)|Strider]]" he meets is "the real Strider". The poem thus appears in that context as a means of identifying Aragorn. Aragorn indeed later quotes the first two lines
column3: not knowing the poem is in the letter
column4: and this does help to confirm his identity.<ref>{{FR|I10}}</ref>  Bilbo himself recites the poem at the [[Council of Elrond]] when [[Boromir]] expresses doubts about Aragorn's claim to be the [[Heir of Isildur]].<ref>{{FR|II2}}</ref>

column1: The first line is clearly a re-working of the traditional proverb "All that glitters is not gold"
column2: reversing its meaning. The second line
column3: perhaps one of the lines from Tolkien's work most often quoted out of context
column4: refers to Aragorn's travels. The third and fourth lines concern Aragorn's heritage
column5: while the remaining lines describe his destiny. The "blade that was broken" refers to the [[Shards of Narsil]]
column6: which is indeed remade for Aragorn.

column2: the Riddle is absent. Strider simply tells his name after Frodo reads the words "His name is Aragorn". Later
column4: Frodo uses the line "the old that is strong does not wither" to refer to Bilbo
column5: and Arwen says "From the ashes a fire shall be woken" when she gives Aragorn Andúril.

column1: '''2003: ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King]]'':'''
:The last four lines are recited by [[Arwen]] upon her return to [[Rivendell]] as she stands before the Shards of Narsil.  She later encourages [[Elrond]] to re-forge the sword
column2: and presumably to deliver it to Aragorn.
